code: @Manual{,   title = {plotscaper: Explore Your Data with Interactive Figures},   author = {Adam Bartonicek},   year = {2024},   note = {R package version 0.1.0},   url = {https://bartonicek.github.io/plotscaper/}, }

what: Explore Your Data with Interactive Figures
title: Explore Your Data with Interactive Figures
text: Plotscaper R package designed making interactive figures geared towards data exploration. plots plotscaper figures support linked selection, well wide variety interactions, including parameter manipulation, zooming, panning, reordering, others.

title: Explore Your Data with Interactive Figures
text: get started, install plotscaper : Next, open RStudio run following code:  viewer, now see something like image , however, version fully interactive (Github doesn’t allow JavaScript README.md, hence image static). Try moving mouse somewhere scatterplot top left figure clicking dragging select points. see corresponding cases get highlighted across plots! many ways interacting plotscaper figures, including: Zooming panning Changing size objects Increasing/decreasing opacity (alpha) Assigning selected cases persistent groups Manipulating parameters histogram binwidth anchor Modifying continuous axis limits Sorting reordering discrete axes Resizing individual plots Click question mark top right corner figure see list available options plus corresponding key/mouse bindings.
code: devtools::install_github("bartonicek/plotscape/packages/plotscaper") library(plotscaper)  layout <- matrix(c(   1, 1, 2, 3,   1, 1, 4, 5,   6, 7, 7, 7 ), ncol = 4, byrow = TRUE)  set_scene(sacramento) |>   add_scatterplot(c("longitude", "latitude")) |>   add_barplot("city") |>   add_histogram(c("sqft")) |>   add_fluctplot(c("beds", "baths")) |>   add_histogram2d(c("sqft", "price")) |>   add_notes() |>   add_parcoords(names(sacramento)) |>   set_layout(layout)

title: Explore Your Data with Interactive Figures
text: bunch things going code used create figure . Let’s walk step step. First, whenever want create plotscaper figure, need set scene, kind global context plots get placed. set scene, run: data data.frame object. ’re using Sacramento housing data set caret package. run code , just get empty rectangle. reason , order things, first need fill scene plots. populate scene plots, can use add_* functions:  code creates interactive figure linked scatterplot barplot. need specify variables want show plot simple character vectors names. Simple . hood, plotscaper figure just htmlwidgets widget. means , render figure, need print underlying object. specifically, print plotscaper scene, htmlwidgets generates underlying HTML, JavaScript, CSS, sends RStudio viewer (kind Web browser). operation lazy - don’t print object, nothing happens: However, printing s generates figure:  can use laziness generate figures programmatically R. example, ’s create interactive scatterplot matrix (SPLOM) Iris dataset:
code: set_scene(data = sacramento) set_scene(sacramento) |>   add_scatterplot(c("longitude", "latitude")) |>   add_barplot("city") s <- set_scene(sacramento) |>   add_scatterplot(c("longitude", "latitude")) |>   add_barplot("city") s # This is the same as print(s) iris_smaller <- iris[, 1:3] keys <- names(iris_smaller)  s <- set_scene(iris_smaller)  # Loop through columns for (i in 1:3) {   for (j in 1:3) {     # Add a scatterplot if row & column no.'s are different     if (i != j) s <- s |> add_scatterplot(c(keys[i], keys[j]))     # Add a histogram if row & column no.'s are the same     else s <- s |> add_histogram(c(keys[i]))    } }  s

title: Explore Your Data with Interactive Figures
text: can control figure layout using set_layout function. function works similarly layout function graphics package. just give function matrix numeric values representing plot ids, figure automatically resizes plots based many equal-sized rectangles grid plot takes . example, ’s can create figure large scatterplot top-left, tall histogram right-hand side, short wide histogram bottom, small section notes (-(e)-plot, pardon pun) bottom-right:  can still resize individual plots pressing holding S key dragging widget bottom right plot area. Note, however, feature bit finicky may result gaps.
code: layout <- matrix(c(   1, 1, 2,   1, 1, 2,   3, 3, 4 ), ncol = 3, byrow = TRUE)  set_scene(sacramento) |>   add_scatterplot(c("sqft", "price")) |>   add_histogram("price") |>   add_histogram("sqft") |>   add_notes() |>   set_layout(layout)

title: Explore Your Data with Interactive Figures
text: section delves deeper properties plotscaper. happy using default figures explore data, feel free skip , however, may still find interesting read. started PhD project, wanted create framework making interactive graphics support certain types interaction box. Specifically, wanted every plot support linked selection, .e. able click click drag objects one plot corresponding cases get highlighted across plots. reason wanted support linked selection allows quickly query different subsets data - select objects one plot immediately see summaries subset data - makes really useful interactive feature lot data visualization researchers swear (see e.g. Buja, Cook, Swayne 1996; Heer Shneiderman 2012; Ward, Grinstein, Keim 2015; Ware 2019). Anyway, alongside linked selection, also wanted able support various kinds plots statistical summaries, , draw draw barplot, make bars display different summary statistic (instead usual counts), e.g. sums means variable. sounds simple enough, right? However, kept running one issue, . wanted plots support linked selection able show different kinds summaries. , wanted treat interaction (linked selection) statistics plots two independent components. Unfortunately, things work, kept hitting head wall. However, , also eventually stumbled upon something think really interesting. now convinced graphics, statistics, interaction inextricably linked, deep, algebraic way, , want create interactive data visualizations look behave sensible ways, need aware . hope can convince - let start laying problem kept running , starting simple static plots.

title: Explore Your Data with Interactive Figures
text: Try see ’s wrong following plot:  plot looks like something might result linked selection, , visually, looks like perfectly fine ggplot2 figure. However, take close look following line: ’re telling ggplot2 want draw bars summarizing y-axis variable average, within levels defined Cartesian product x fill variables (.e. table x rows fill columns). However, ’s one important argument applied function call, ggplot2 default don’t see unless specify explicitly: using using fill aesthetic geom_bar (well geoms), ggplot2 applies stack transformation default. case bars, transformation stacks bars vertically top , effectively summing heights coloured sub-bars. herein lies problem: height stacked bars represent now? Since stacking bars effectively summing underlying statistic, whole bar now represents sum group averages. meaningful summary statistic - “sum averages” quantity many people care know interpret. kind problem can easily trip data visualization rookie, good number data visualization researchers warned : “Stacking useful sum amounts represented individual stacked bars meaningful amount” (Wilke 2019, 52). “[…] important element’s size used display statistic, statistic must summable. Stacking bars represent counts, sums, percentages fine, stacked bar chart bars show average values generally meaningless.” (Wills 2011, 112). Alright, might say, sum averages, since summing sums fine, taking average averages? Unfortunately, correct either - mean group means grand mean: researchers warned : “[…] ensure aggregate statistics always computed input data, users inadvertantly compute e.g., averages averages, can easily lead misinterpretation.” (Wu 2022) ? ’re familiar ggplot2, may thinking one handy solution right now: instead stacking bars, let’s use dodging plot side side:  works well static graphics. However, interactive graphics, dodging several issues. Take look following two rows plots:  rows, represent data; top row use stacking, bottom row use dodging. can imagine barplots produced linked selection, dark-blue bars representing selected cases cases selected move left right. Notice top row, overall contour plot remains constant even number selected cases changes: always tall left bar, tall right bar, short middle bar, heights highlighted dark-blue sections fluctuate. true dodging. dodging, since plot selected non-selected cases side--side, selection can affect overall shape plot dramatically - bars may shrink grow, even pop existence (see left-plot bottom row). may impact parts plot - see top y-axis limits changes across plots. Thus, want implement selection linked barplot dodging, tough choice whether make axes react response selection . make axes reactive user always able see data, however, selection happens, axis limits reset lose context provide. don’t make axes reactive, risk bars growing outside plotting area. don’t worry case stacked barplot since selection affect height tallest bar. Also, bit subjective preference, find interactive figures change gradually visually pleasing easier read figures objects fluctuate rapidly. haven’t found much research support claim broadly. article Hullman et al. (2013), found , presenting sequences static graphics, people prefer sequences plots change gradually rather abruptly.
code: theme_set(theme_bw() +              theme(panel.grid = element_blank(),                   panel.border = element_blank(),                   panel.background = element_rect(fill = "whitesmoke")))  ggplot(mtcars, aes(x = cyl, y = mpg, fill = am)) +   geom_bar(stat = "summary", fun = mean) +   scale_fill_manual(values = c("#92c9f6", "#377eb8")) +   guides(fill = "none") geom_bar(stat = "summary", fun = mean) geom_bar(stat = "summary", fun = mean, position = "stack") mean(1:3) #> [1] 2 mean(mean(1:2), 3) #> [1] 1.5 ggplot(mtcars, aes(x = cyl, y = mpg, fill = am)) +   geom_bar(stat = "summary", fun = mean, position = "dodge") +   scale_fill_manual(values = c("#92c9f6", "#377eb8")) +   guides(fill = "none")

title: Explore Your Data with Interactive Figures
text: ever linked selection sums counts, can use stacking highlight selected cases? seems bit limiting. perhaps ’s another way. quotes , Wilke (2019) Wills (2011) said quantity represented stacked bar “meaningful”. mean? Well, try rephrase Wilke Wills getting , say sums particularly nice kind summary statistic : Sum grouped sums equal sum everything. words, can take sets data, sum individually, sum sums, ’ll get result first combined sets one big set summed . words, sums preserve set union. makes possible draw highlighted parts bars objects, know combine (sum) two sums, ’ll get valid summary union underlying cases data. statistics behave way? replace word “sum” placeholder, example “foo”: Foo grouped foos equal foo everything. , actually turns statistics behave way. example, product products also valid product cases: likewise, maximum maximum also valid maximum cases: make idea precise? Turns mathematical concept encapsulates .

title: Explore Your Data with Interactive Figures
text: “Monoid” sounds scary ’s really nothing complicated. ’s just three things: set MM binary operation ⊗:M×M→M\otimes: M \times M \M neutral element e∈\M Subject two rules: Unitality: x⊗e=e⊗x=xx \otimes e = e \otimes x = x Associativity: x⊗(y⊗z)=(x⊗y)⊗zx \otimes (y \otimes z) = (x \otimes y) \otimes z means , monoid, bunch things MM way combining things ⊗\otimes, , combine things, order doesn’t matter. also neutral element ee, , combined anything else, just yields thing back. Typical examples monoids include mentioned sums, products, maximums (, set MM real numbers neutral units 0, 1, −∞-\infty respectively). Counterexamples include -mentioned means, well , example, exponentiation (isn’t associative: (xy)z≠x(yz)(x^y)^z \neq x^{(y^z)}. Monoids fundamental concept abstract algebra category theory (see e.g. Fong Spivak 2019; Lawvere Schanuel 2009), also heavily used functional programming (see e.g. Milewski 2018). purposes, important exact property looking - preserve set union. Suppose two disjoint subsets data ,B⊆DA, B \subseteq D, can summarize monoidal summary F: F()=a1⊗a2⊗…⊗anF() = a_1 \otimes a_2 \otimes \ldots \otimes a_n , just take elements AA “sum” together one value (“sum” something else). Now, summarize AA BB combine summaries, get result summarizing union: F()⊗F(B)=(a1⊗a2⊗…)⊗(b1⊗b2⊗…bn)=a1⊗a2⊗…⊗b1⊗b2⊗…bn(associativity: brackets don’t matter)=F(∪B)\begin{aligned} F() \otimes F(B) &= (a_1 \otimes a_2 \otimes \ldots a_n) \otimes (b_1 \otimes b_2 \otimes \ldots b_n) \\ &= a_1 \otimes a_2 \otimes \ldots a_n \otimes b_1 \otimes b_2 \otimes \ldots b_n \qquad \text{(associativity: brackets matter)} \\ &= F(\cup B) \end{aligned} means , monoids, can compare nested subsets data. precisely want highlight cases plot: want compare summary selected cases (F()F()) vs. everything (F(∪B)F(\cup B)). important caveats regarding comparison multiple selected groups monotonicity. title: Explore Your Data with Interactive Figures
text: plotscaper, know little bit JavaScript, can use available plots display monoidal summary statistics, using something called reducers. create reducer, need two things: initial function: function produces neutral element ee reduce function: function takes two values (MM) combines together, operation associative unital currently need JavaScript functions. example, suppose want display barplot maximums positive numeric variable. can use following JavaScript arrow function initial function: function takes arguments just produces value zero. computer science lingo, kind “dumb” function called thunk. case, function technically just value, however, thunks general, way pointers work JavaScript. one thing need reduce function: just simple function takes two numbers returns bigger one, using built Math.max JavaScript function. ’s . might asking know whether operation function associative unital. figure : try couple candidate values & see properties hold. plotscaper doesn’t know either - give function doesn’t properties still try make interactive plot. can’t know doesn’t know values try; properties hold handful numbers others. functions behind can actually support values numbers, haven’t tried implement plot like yet ’ll see future. Anyway, ’s can create barplot maximums plotscaper:  Since maximum monoid, highlighting work expected! However, one selected group: multiple groups selected, may able see bars; reason math. TODO
code: () => 0 (x, y) => Math.max(x, y) library(htmlwidgets)  # Make the reducer - it really is just an R list() underneath max_reducer <- reducer(   name = "max",   initialfn = "() => 0",   reducefn = "(x, y) => Math.max(x, y)" )  set_scene(sacramento) |>   add_scatterplot(c("sqft", "price")) |>   add_barplot(c("city", "price"),                options = list(reducer = max_reducer)) # Specify the reducer in plot options

title: Explore Your Data with Interactive Figures
text: performance wasn’t number one concern plotscaper, can perform fairly well moderately-sized data sets (thanks largely work smart people optimized JavaScript engines like V8). example, want put plotscaper stress test, try creating figure entire diamonds dataset ggplot2 package:  50,000 cases, dragging select points scatterplot becomes bit sluggish machine, still fast enough make figure feel “interactive” rather “slideshow”. mileage may vary. Note slowdown due rendering rather computation - removing scatterplot 50,000 points makes interactions lot snappier. Frustratingly, seems small slowdown interacting figure RStudio Viewer rather directly browser. Interestingly, seem related dataset size. ’m familiar RStudio internals idea might , now, want faster interactions recommend just opening browser window, e.g. clicking icon top right viewer:  (know reason behind slowdown /fix , please email abar435@aucklanduni.ac.nz) Anyway, need fast figures larger data sets, recommend taking following steps: Run figure browser rather viewer Use plots summarize data (e.g. barplots, 2D histograms), rather plots show data points Take subsample data

title: Add plot to an interactive scene — add_plot
text: function used internally specialized wrapper functions add_scatterplot add_barplot, recommend use functions instead. Note variable encodings specified via encoding argument different aesthetic encodings used Grammar Graphics (GoG)-based systems ggplot2. , code like following:   work. , plotscaper, data variables mapped intermediate "summary" variables may subject statistical transformations, happens can summary variables mapped aesthetic variables. .e. three-step model: $$\textbf{data} \overset{\text{summarize}}{\longrightarrow} \textbf{summaries} \overset{\text{encode}}{\longrightarrow} \textbf{aesthetics}$$ reason departure GoG style specifying aesthetics interactive plots difficult express clean 1--1 mapping data aesthetics. example, spinogram (scaled version histogram - click histogram press "N" key), y-axis variable scaled count, x-axis variable cumulative (absolute) count. Neither variables come directly data, represent transformation underlying summary variable (count within bins). fact, underlying summary variable spinogram exactly one histogram uses - just transformed differently mapped different aesthetics kind plot.

title: Shiny bindings for plotscaper — plotscaper-shiny

title: Shiny bindings for plotscaper — plotscaper-shiny
text: outputId output variable read width, height Must valid CSS unit (like '100%', '400px', 'auto') number, coerced string 'px' appended. expr expression generates plotscaper env environment evaluate expr. quoted expr quoted expression (quote())? useful want save expression variable.

title: Construct a Reducer — reducer

what: Set up an interactive scene — set_scene
title: Set up an interactive scene — set_scene
text: function constructs skeleton interactive plotscaper figure. Specifically, parses data JSON, creates object class htmlwidget sends additional information necessary set figure, variable types, URL websocket server (interactive), etc.. figure gets rendered resulting htmlwidget object gets printed.

title: Set up an interactive scene — set_scene
code: set_scene(   data = NULL,   options = NULL,   width = NULL,   height = NULL,   elementId = NULL )

title: Set up an interactive scene — set_scene
text: data dataframe converted JSON (missing values currently supported). options list options width Width scene height Height scene elementId id element render widget

title: Set up an interactive scene — set_scene
text: object class htmlwidget

title: Set up an interactive scene — set_scene
